The paper draws on a few distinct types of data. In Chapter 1 the author uses an approach based on multiple measures derived from surname‐based records to assess intergenerational mobility (an unspecified, nonstandard dataset – categorized here as ‘others’), in Chapter 2 the study employs rich administrative/registry data from Sweden, and in Chapter 3 the analysis is based on simulation exercises evaluating teacher effectiveness (i.e. no external dataset). The most clearly identifiable real-world dataset is the rich administrative data for Sweden, which falls under category 2.

The abstracts employ at least two distinct types of datasets. Two of the papers—the one on teenage childbearing and the one on teacher‐student gender matching—appear to use standard administrative or registry records (e.g. school performance records, teacher assignment records), which corresponds best to category 2. In contrast, the papers on intergenerational schooling effects and on mobility/assortative mating rely on explicitly Swedish data that link parents and children (typical of the high‐quality register data used in Sweden), corresponding to category 6. (No specific dataset names were provided in the abstracts.)
